sentences_tone.text: Apple's New MacBook Pro Is Killing It (And The Competition) - Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksApple's New MacBook Pro Is Killing It (And The Competition)Nov.10.16 | About: Apple Inc. (AAPL) Mark Hibben Follow Long only, tech, chipmakers, softwareSend MessageSummaryApple's new MacBook Pros appear to be selling better than any previous Pro notebooks.The OLED Touch Bar is the key discriminator from previous Pro generations as well as other notebook PCs.Apple seems to be betting on the Touch Bar to drive MacBook Pro sales growth for many years to come.Despite consternation and complaints about changes in the new MacBook Pro line-up, Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) appears to be doing very well with its new notebooks.
According to Slice Intelligence, the Pro has already generated more than seven times the sales as the Retina Display MacBook during an equivalent launch period.
And launch sales of the Pro already dwarf cumulative sales to date of the Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) Surface Book.
Click to enlarge Source: Apple A Little Microsoft Inspiration In an interview, Apple's Phil Schiller claimed that the new MacBook Pros have outsold every previous Pro model on Apple's online store.
The Pros with Touch Bar are still on back order on the Apple Online Store, with shipping delays of 4-5 weeks.
Of course, it can always be argued that this only indicates lack of supply/demand balance, and not the magnitude of sales.

However, this chart from Slice Intelligence neatly sums up where MacBook Pro stands in terms of sales relative to major notebook PC competitors, including those from Asus (OTC:ASUUY), Dell, and Lenovo (OTCPK:LNVGY).
Click to enlarge In just its first five days of sales, revenue already is about 3.7 times total cumulative revenue of the Surface Book, and about 10 times the revenue for the other models listed.

It's a very impressive achievement, and much of the credit for this must go to Apple's OLED Touch Bar since this is the key innovation that sets the MacBook Pros apart from the competition and from previous Pro generations.
Interestingly, the Touch Bar concept isn't completely original.

An article in Patently Apple points out that back in 2010, Microsoft had experimented with an Adaptive Keyboard concept that used a long, thin touchscreen positioned above a traditional keyboard, as shown in the image below:
Source: Microsoft As shown in the video below, Microsoft not only provided a touchscreen, but also placed small displays underneath each physical key.
This allowed the keys to have programmable functions that would be reflected in the individual key displays.

What Apple has done is to combine both of the concepts of the touchscreen and configurable keys into the Touch Bar, which is more flexible, and a little more practical, since it doesn't require placing individual displays underneath each physical key.

What to do When You Can't Patent It Apple's take on the Microsoft keyboard may have been developed independently, but undoubtedly, when AAPL looked into patenting the Touch Bar (such exercises are routine), it would have discovered the existence of the Microsoft work.
Probably, Apple has no means of patenting the Touch Bar, which means it would have few options to prevent others from copying it.
Lacking the option of patent protection, I believe that Apple has done the next best thing by trying to tie up available production of the Touch Bar.
And not just this year, but many years into the future.
This is the better explanation for an observation recently made by analysts at J.P. Morgan, and widely reported in Apple oriented media.
They noted that Apple's fiscal 2016 SEC 10-K annual report contained manufacturing purchase obligations that stretched as much as five years in the future.
These obligations totaled $3.896 billion, as shown in the table below, excerpted from the report.
Click to enlarge What's interesting about this is that past 10-Ks have not shown such future commitments.
For instance, the same table from fiscal 2015 shown below has zero commitments, and so did the fiscal 2014 10-K.
Click to enlarge J.P. Morgan was quick to jump to the conclusion that Apple must be committing to buy OLED screens for coming generations of iPhone.
This seems to be yet another repetition of the "OLED envy" thesis that has been so popular among analysts.
Apple's iPhone LCD screens are so inferior to OLED, that the company would even buy them from Samsung (OTC:SSNLF).
Except that the thesis is bogus.
With the new wide-color gamut displays in the new iPhone 7, the displays are not inferior to OLED.
Far from it.
They provide more accurate color, with better response uniformity than OLED.
They will also probably last longer since they don't have OLED's problems of blue pixel life limitation.
They also don't suffer from the OLED problem of screen burn-in.
And finally, Apple's LCD screens are more energy efficient when used the way that is most common, with a white or light color background (as when reading text on a web page).
At this point, given all the technical drawbacks of OLED, I don't buy into the thesis that a move to OLED is inevitable.
Apple may choose to skip the technology altogether.
But, in any case, the future purchase obligations almost certainly don't reflect a shift to OLED.
The problem with the OLED interpretation of the future obligations is that the dollar amounts are too small.
According to IHS, the display/touchscreen of the Samsung Galaxy S7 costs $55.
Let's assume about half of that is the OLED display.
Apple will probably sell at least 200 million iPhones in fiscal 2018 and the same in 2019 since it sold 211.9 million in fiscal 2016.
If even a quarter of these have OLED displays, then the dollar commitment that Apple would need to make would be $2.75 billion, not the $939 million shown for the first 1-3 years.
I believe that the commitment is for Touch Bar devices.
The numbers fit a lot better.

Assuming each Touch Bar costs $15, and assuming that Apple will sell at most 20 million MacBook Pros per year in fiscal 2017-2019, then the total bill would come to about $900 million, a pretty good fit to the projected expense.
Investor Takeaway Considering that Apple is motivated to limit copying of the Touch Bar, this really looks like the company preemptively tying up its key suppliers.
These suppliers have been reported to be Wistron and an unidentified Singapore company.
Early on, it was reported that Apple's Singapore supplier was having production difficulties with the Touch Bar, which was why Wistron was brought on board.
Apple normally doesn't provide such long-term commitments, but appears to have done so in order to keep its suppliers from building Touch Bars for others.
If building the Touch Bars requires unique expertise, this would be an effective way to keep the technology out of the hands of competitors.
It's a gutsy strategy that is not wholly without risk.
Apple may miscalculate the demand for the new MacBook Pro and be stuck with Touch Bars it doesn't need.
However, as noted above, Apple doesn't appear to have miscalculated at all.
Strong demand for the MacBook Pros confirms my thesis that the key mission of the MacBook Pros is to provide a compelling upgrade path for current MacBook users.
Pent-up demand for the new Pros seems to be sufficient to get Macs outgrowing the PC industry in 2017.
2017 is starting to look like a growth year for Apple on the strength of the iPhone 7 and new MacBook Pros.
I remain long Apple and recommend it as a buy for investors with a 3-5 year investment horizon.
Disclosure: I am/we are long AAPL.
